commit_message:
Allow to override t-h-t 'Cloud*' params undercloud

Allow to parametrize the hardcoded 'undercloud' domain name.
F.e. RDOcloud uses an 'rdocloud' domain, therefore some DNS things might be
failing with the hardcoded value.
The default domain name remains unchanged. It can be
overriden with a new '--local-domain' option as well.

Related-bug: #1698349
Partial-bug: #1733873

Change-Id: Iad63142b241f9f7f0bbef68473f18b69f36daf76
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/98/522298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | For containerized undercloud deploy, changed subdomains placement order from 'undercloud.storage.localdomain' to 'storage.undercloud.localdomain' for endpoints' FQDNs. Removed hardcoded default value 'undercloud' in the domain name. It is now expected to come from t-h-t 'Cloud*' params. fixes: - | For containerized undercloud deploy, there is no more hardcoded 'undercloud' domain name configured by default. New option 'local_domain' allows to override FQDNs coming from t-h-t 'Cloud*' params. Changed subdomains placement order from 'undercloud.storage.localdomain' to 'storage.undercloud.localdomain'. That allows elsewhere to consistently propagate name changes to the overcloud/undercloud endpoints. Note that default domain for undercloud is expected from t-h-t from now on.

commit_message:
Fix glance config generation when using NFS

This commit sets the 'tripleo::glance::nfs_mount::edit_fstab' variable
to false to prevent the glance_api to write to /etc/fstab and fail in
the case we're using an NFS backend.

This also updates the NFS mount option and mount point to align with
the config from the puppet-tripleo module at:

https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/glance/nfs_mount.pp

Change-Id: Ied27fac67d28b3104441ada469942a19e3c07a89
Closes-Bug: #1732928
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/03/521103/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: volumes: - "/etc/fstab:/etc/fstab:ro"

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-16 19:44:12.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/source/conf.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient/commit/bc94ee1bf4da2a1907e44539af36166c0cc87eaa', 'message': "Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at

Change-Id: I1c53f58e838e000711261f54dfd9e705e2495e32
"}]
commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I1c53f58e838e000711261f54dfd9e705e2495e32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/29/520729/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Release notes are version independent. release = ''version = ''
deleted_lines: import pbr.version # The version info for the project you're documenting, acts as replacement for # |version| and |release|, also used in various other places throughout the # built documents. #manilaclient_version = pbr.version.VersionInfo('python-manilaclient') release = manilaclient_version.version_string_with_vcs() # The short X.Y version. version = manilaclient_version.canonical_version_string()

subject: Add task to allow creation of provided roles
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-08 19:48:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/64cf82b6ae6f1f4c12c5a97a210348918443ee29', 'message': "Add task to allow creation of provided roles

Some tempest tests require that a specific role is available for use.
Add a new variable, `tempest_roles`, to allow users to provide a list of
roles to create.

The existing tasks that create the 'reseller_admin' and 'remote_image'
roles have been removed. The correctly named 'ResellerAdmin' role is
already created by the os_swift role and the 'remote_image' is no longer
required since the glance tests make use of an admin user.

Change-Id: I7987c5a4dbf50e97322a5b348c3cbd817b2672d6
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-11-14 06:14:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/12763f825f78017f5ca44e54f330a208bd048155', 'message': "Add task to allow creation of provided roles

Some tempest tests require that a specific role is available for use.
Add a new variable, `tempest_roles`, to allow users to provide a list of
roles to create.

The existing tasks that create the 'reseller_admin' and 'remote_image'
roles have been removed. The correctly named 'ResellerAdmin' role is
already created by the os_swift role and the 'remote_image' is no longer
required since the glance tests make use of an admin user.

commit_message:
Add task to allow creation of provided roles

Some tempest tests require that a specific role is available for use.
Add a new variable, `tempest_roles`, to allow users to provide a list of
roles to create.

The existing tasks that create the 'reseller_admin' and 'remote_image'
roles have been removed. The correctly named 'ResellerAdmin' role is
already created by the os_swift role and the 'remote_image' is no longer
required since the glance tests make use of an admin user.

Depends-On: I66b7c639494d98fdb3baa52fe56c670e32dea3ce
Change-Id: I7987c5a4dbf50e97322a5b348c3cbd817b2672d6

commit_message:
Start sequence at 1 for deploy steps playbook

We should start the sequence at 1 instead of 0, since all our puppet
manifests assume the first step is 1. Trying to run our puppet manifests
with a hieradata value of step=0 actually results in an error because no
classes are included.

Change-Id: I93dc8b4cefbd729ba7afa3a4d81b4ac95344cac2
Closes-Bug: #1717292

added_lines: --- fixes: - Start sequence at 1 for the downloaded deploy steps playbook instead of 0. The first step should be 1 since that is what the puppet manifests expect.

commit_message:
Blacklist test_boot_server_from_encrypted_volume_luks in ocata

This test have been added in tempest 16.1.0 which has been promoted
to ocata but TripleO does not configure legacy encryption key manager
properly and barbican is not availabe in overcloud.

Closes-Bug: #1733574

subject: LOCI - OCI images for OpenStack
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-20 21:06:00.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/a85eafd1e27c787420836d95d4731c9cf4d9eb05', 'message': 'LOCI - OCI images for OpenStack

The mission of LOCI is to provide tooling that can output OCI[0]
compliant images in a CI/CD friendly way. A major goal, which we have
achieved, is to be able to build OpenStack images in a completely
air-gapped environment. Currently, the LOCI gates work completely by
consuming OpenStack-Infra mirrors for packages, pypi, and DockerHub
images.

LOCI has always been close to the OpenStack ecosystem. We are one of the
first ones to use secrets in zuulv3 outside of Infra themselves. We also
have worked with other projects to produce images per commit to the
services[1][2]. We extended openstack-infra/bindep[3] to support a new
syntax that allowed us to further simplify the LOCI build process while
making auditing of packages easier[4].

Some of the major benefits of LOCI images include:
  * Standard tooling for building (currently using Docker build)
  * Fast build times, most services output an image under 2 minutes
  * Small size, the LOCI Keystone image is under 40MB on Debian
  * CI/CD friendly, LOCI builds services entirely seperate from each
    other, so you can build Keystone seperately from Neutron without
    losing any benefits listed above
  * python3 support (though not all OpenStack services support python3)

LOCI itself only provides the tooling to build the images. It has no
deployment engine, and never will. The consumers of LOCI include several
offical OpenStack projects, namely Cinder[5] and OpenStack-Helm[6].
Outside of this, there are at least two companies using LOCI images
internally. Additionally, individuals such as myself and Chris Hoge
(hogepodge) use these images in personal deployments.

We will be implementing two periodic jobs that will reconsume zuulv3
jobs from Kolla-Ansible and OpenStack-Helm when those gates are ready.
This will allow us to demonstrate the functionality of LOCI images in
two seperate OpenStack projects on a regular basis. We have discussed
this with both PTLs from both communities and both are happy to work
with this us to make this happen.

While LOCI has been around for a year, we will be making our debut 1.0.0
stable tag for the OpenStack Queens release.

We are working on moving our meeting to one of the #openstack-meeting
channels to be in compliance with the OpenStack Project Team guidelines
as mentioned here[7][8].

To address the "4 opens":
  * Open Source: check! All code is license compatible
  * Open Commnuity:
      - We have not held any elections yet, but given acceptance by the
        TC we would do so at the next available cycle.
      - We are not, as a group, affiliated with any individual company.
        In fact, the majority of the work done in LOCI was on personal
        time for the contirbutors
  * Open Development:
      - We have been using the OpenStack eco system extensively
      - We are cooperating with existing projects as shown by the points
        in previous paragraphs as well as the links below
  * Open Design:
      - We have, in an unofficial capacity, done most of our design work
        at the PTGs or Summits. We would love to do this in an official
        capaciity!
      - We primarily use IRC for collaboration, but I do monitor the
        mailing list. I suspect as time moves forward, and development
        slows, the mailing list will get used more, as has been the case
        with other projects.

[0] https://www.opencontainers.org/
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512398/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512793/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506502/
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512063/3/bindep.txt
[5] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/tree/master/contrib/block-box
[6] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/472961/
[7] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/open-community.html#public-meetings-on-irc
[8] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512471/

Change-Id: I4152237a2fbde5f827aae4524f87e7bf2798e956
'}]
commit_message:
LOCI - OCI images for OpenStack

The mission of LOCI is to provide tooling that can output OCI[0]
compliant images in a CI/CD friendly way. A major goal, which we have
achieved, is to be able to build OpenStack images in a completely
air-gapped environment. Currently, the LOCI gates work completely by
consuming OpenStack-Infra mirrors for packages, pypi, and DockerHub
images.

LOCI has always been close to the OpenStack ecosystem. We are one of the
first ones to use secrets in zuulv3 outside of Infra themselves. We also
have worked with other projects to produce images per commit to the
services[1][2]. We extended openstack-infra/bindep[3] to support a new
syntax that allowed us to further simplify the LOCI build process while
making auditing of packages easier[4].

Some of the major benefits of LOCI images include:
  * Standard tooling for building (currently using Docker build)
  * Fast build times, most services output an image under 2 minutes
  * Small size, the LOCI Keystone image is under 40MB on Debian
  * CI/CD friendly, LOCI builds services entirely seperate from each
    other, so you can build Keystone seperately from Neutron without
    losing any benefits listed above
  * python3 support (though not all OpenStack services support python3)

LOCI itself only provides the tooling to build the images. It has no
deployment engine, and never will. The consumers of LOCI include several
offical OpenStack projects, namely Cinder[5] and OpenStack-Helm[6].
Outside of this, there are at least two companies using LOCI images
internally. Additionally, individuals such as myself and Chris Hoge
(hogepodge) use these images in personal deployments.

We will be implementing two periodic jobs that will reconsume zuulv3
jobs from Kolla-Ansible and OpenStack-Helm when those gates are ready.
This will allow us to demonstrate the functionality of LOCI images in
two seperate OpenStack projects on a regular basis. We have discussed
this with both PTLs from both communities and both are happy to work
with this us to make this happen.

While LOCI has been around for a year, we will be making our debut 1.0.0
stable tag for the OpenStack Queens release.

We are working on moving our meeting to one of the #openstack-meeting
channels to be in compliance with the OpenStack Project Team guidelines
as mentioned here[7][8].

To address the "4 opens":
  * Open Source: check! All code is license compatible
  * Open Commnuity:
      - We have not held any elections yet, but given acceptance by the
        TC we would do so at the next available cycle.
      - We are not, as a group, affiliated with any individual company.
        In fact, the majority of the work done in LOCI was on personal
        time for the contirbutors
  * Open Development:
      - We have been using the OpenStack eco system extensively
      - We are cooperating with existing projects as shown by the points
        in previous paragraphs as well as the links below
  * Open Design:
      - We have, in an unofficial capacity, done most of our design work
        at the PTGs or Summits. We would love to do this in an official
        capaciity!
      - We primarily use IRC for collaboration, but I do monitor the
        mailing list. I suspect as time moves forward, and development
        slows, the mailing list will get used more, as has been the case
        with other projects.

[0] https://www.opencontainers.org/
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512398/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512793/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/506502/

commit_message:
Add a new hook ``collect_artifacts_hook``

Right now, there's a lot of project specific code in the cleanup_host
function. This patch adds a generic way for projects to collect logs,
configuration files, etc. regardless of the job exit code.

This hook will be called unconditionally as the last step before
cleanup.

Change-Id: I2fd2afd06b73cab68e427c94e4d2064fe727702f
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/41/522241/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Run collect_artifacts_hook regardless of the return value with_timeout call_hook_if_defined "collect_artifacts_hook"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-31 13:21:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/1ad14317301e74e06e64e15a0c88d47e3e4f838a', 'message': 'Add supports-accessible-upgrade tag to ironic*

This adds the "supports-accessible-upgrade" tag to ironic and

During an ironic upgrade, the bare metal nodes that end users access are

ironic-inspector only deals with bare metal nodes prior to them being

Change-Id: I20941939e9f2331c6a0983e3c14c988cae936bd2
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-10-31 18:25:53.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/5849ea5395b7a80e60e98dc967400dee200c5f40', 'message': 'Add supports-accessible-upgrade tag to ironic*

This adds the "supports-accessible-upgrade" tag to ironic and
ironic-inspector. They both meet the criteria for this tag:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/assert_supports-accessible-upgrade.html#requirements

During an ironic upgrade, the bare metal nodes that end users access
are unaffected. this is tested in gate, via the grenade jobs. For
example, in the 'ironic-grenade-dsvm' job, nova is used to get a bare
metal instance from old ironic. After old ironic is shut down and
before new ironic is started up, grenade runs the resource phase:
'verify_noapi pre-upgrade'. Although ironic's verify_noapi() is a
noop [1], nova comes to the rescue with it's verify_noapi() [2]
where it pings its bare metal instance (which it got from ironic).

ironic-inspector only deals with bare metal nodes prior to them being
available to end users, so it doesn't touch any resource that is
accessible to the end user.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/7f924cf30f546ae76eb149ae86201073ded396b2/devstack/upgrade/resources.sh#L123

[2] https://github.com/openstack-dev/grenade/blob/dbee4eed16cc0b2a2143f18936d6c85fd3940da0/projects/60_nova/resources.sh#L136

Change-Id: I20941939e9f2331c6a0983e3c14c988cae936bd2
'}]
commit_message:
Add supports-accessible-upgrade tag to ironic*

This adds the "supports-accessible-upgrade" tag to ironic and
ironic-inspector. They both meet the criteria for this tag:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/assert_supports-accessible-upgrade.html#requirements

During an ironic upgrade, the bare metal nodes that end users access
are unaffected. this is tested in gate, via the grenade jobs. For
example, in the 'ironic-grenade-dsvm' job, nova is used to get a bare
metal instance from old ironic. After old ironic is shut down and
before new ironic is started up, grenade runs the resource phase:
'verify_noapi pre-upgrade'. Although ironic's verify_noapi() is a
noop [1], nova comes to the rescue with it's verify_noapi() [2]
where it pings its bare metal instance (which it got from ironic).

ironic-inspector only deals with bare metal nodes prior to them being
available to end users, so it doesn't touch any resource that is
accessible to the end user.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/7f924cf30f546ae76eb149ae86201073ded396b2/devstack/upgrade/resources.sh#L123

[2] https://github.com/openstack-dev/grenade/blob/dbee4eed16cc0b2a2143f18936d6c85fd3940da0/projects/60_nova/resources.sh#L136

Change-Id: I20941939e9f2331c6a0983e3c14c988cae936bd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/71/516671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - assert:supports-accessible-upgrade - assert:supports-accessible-upgrade
